utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Kites, ho!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Kites ho!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Kites ho!

utterance.speaker: All three
utterance.content: Kites, ho!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me. You’re misusing the word ho. It’s an interjection used to call attention to a destination, not an object, as in, uh, Land, ho! Or, uh, Westward, ho!

utterance.speaker: The three guys
utterance.content: Kites, ho!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, guys. What you doing? Going out to discover electricity?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If you’re referring to the work of Benjamin Franklin, he did not discover electricity, he merely used a kite to determine that lightning consists of electricity. He also invented the Franklin stove, bifocals and the flexible urinary catheter. Kites, ho.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We’re heading out for some kite fighting.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Kite fighting?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. It’s an extremely competitive, cutthroat sport.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, actually, the risk of throat cutting is very low. On the other hand, severe string burn is a real and ever-Present danger.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You want to come watch?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, gee, sounds amazing, but, um, I’ve got some friends coming over. Not a big thing, we’re just gonna watch the Nebraska game.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Football, sure.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Good guess.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I would’ve invited you, but I know you’re not a football fan.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, I’m not, so, great. You’ve got plans doing something you like, I’ve got plans doing something I like, so it’s good.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, maybe we’ll hang out later, you know, after everybody’s gone.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, great.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: See ya.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, this sucks.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I got bored and drifted off. Where exactly in the interaction did the sucking lie?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Leonard just realized that Penny’s been hiding him from her friends because he’s a tiny, little man who flies kites.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that certainly would suck.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wolowitz is trying to outflank us. Let out some string, add altitude and I’ll go under and cut his line.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why wouldn’t Penny want her friends to meet me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Focus, Leonard, focus! The heat of battle is upon us, the dogs of war are unleashed.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Maybe Koothrappali’s right, maybe I embarrass her.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re embarrassing me right now, a grown man worrying about such nonsense when in the middle of flying kites.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry won’t bring their kites down. Ow! String burn! String burn!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, they think we’re flanking, they’re playing right into our hands. On the count of three, we execute the flying scissor. One, two…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Whoa! Did you see that?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: See what?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That chick, she smiled at me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, she didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes, she did.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Come on, scissors, scissors!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hold my line.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Wait, what are you doing? I can’t scissors by myself! Howard! Come back!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Victory!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Son of a bitch.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You’re a sucky friend, you know that? A sucky, sucky friend.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What was I supposed to do? She gave me that come-hither look.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: If she gave you any look at l. It was a you suck look.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I would’ve caught up to her if I hadn’t pulled a hammy.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, please, you weigh 80 pounds. You don’t have a hammy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, Penny doesn’t want me around her friends, I embarrass her. What else could it be?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, her actions could be out of concern for your feelings. Perhaps she’s excluded you from these gatherings because she’s scouting for a new mate and doesn’t want to do it in front of you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, how kind of her.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Agreed. Most primates don’t show that sort of discretion. A female bonobo will copulate with a new male in front of the old one without so much as a how do you do?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You always do this, you know? You ditch me for a woman you don’t have a shot with.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I totally had a shot.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: With a woman you were chasing through a park? That’s not a shot, that’s a felony. What’s worse, it cost me my prized Patang fighting kite. Sheldon, I don’t suppose there’s any chance you could give me my kite back?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, Raj, but the rules of aerial warfare dictate at the fallen kite go to the victor. And without rules, the competition has no meaning. And without meaning, the following would be an empty gesture. I have your kite. I have your kite.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How was your football party?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It was pretty good. We won.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, that’s excellent. It’s a weird figure of speech, isn’t it, we won when you weren’t

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m glad to hear it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, hey, on a related subject, are you embarrassed to have me around your friends?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, my god, no. Why would you ask that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, you know, I just noticed I haven’t really met any of them.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sure you have.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, yeah, no, I met the huge ex-boyfriend and the smaller yet still larger than me ex-boyfriend. Were they here today?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Of course not. Why would they be? Why would I ask? Why am I rambling? Why don’t you stop me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard, look, if you want to meet my friends, that would be great. I just, you know, I didn’t want you to be bored.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I wouldn’t be bored. Why would I be bored?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, ’cause they’re not genius scientists.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny, I like all sorts of people. In fact, some of my best friends aren’t geniuses.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Like who?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, some of my Facebook friends aren’t geniuses. My point is, if we’re going to be a couple, I should be friends with your friends.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, great. Well, then why don’t you come over next Saturday and watch the game with us.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Another football game?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: They have them every week.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Did not know that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You wanted to meet my friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure, sure, just I don’t know much about football.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, that’s okay, a lot of the guys’ girlfriends don’t know football. They just kind of drink and talk in the kitchen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, a complete pass. First down, New England. I think I’m starting to get this.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Really? The only thing I’ve learned in the last two hours is that American men love drinking beer, pee too often and have trouble getting erections.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Focus on the game, not the commercials, Raj.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m just saying, maybe if you people cut back on the beer, you could get out of the bathroom and satisfy your women without pharmaceutical help.

utterance.speaker: Howard (arriving)
utterance.content: Raj, what are you doing here? You were supposed to help me pimp out my Vespa.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m sorry, are you under the impression that we’re still friends?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh come on, you’re not still grinding on the kite thing, are you?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s not just the kite thing. Every time we go some place, you think you can just dump me whenever someone prettier comes along, even though you don’t have a shot with them.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But I had a shot with that jogger.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fine. Paint green flames on your little scooter with her.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s not a little scooter. It’s the second biggest Vespa they make! Are you watching football?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There’s no fooling you. Now, what is this sacks statistic they put up there?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All I know about Saks is, my mother shops there.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sacks, sacks…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s football nomenclature for when a quarterback is tackled behind the line of scrimmage.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Huh… Scrimmage…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The line of scrimmage is the imaginary transverse line separating the offence from the defence.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon knows football?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Apparently.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I mean, Quidditch, sure. But football?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, how do you know this stuff?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I grew up in Texas. Football is ubiquitous in Texas. Pro football, college football, high school football, peewee football, in fact, every form of football except the original, European football, which most Texans believe to be a Commie plot.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Unbelievable.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you’re interested, I also know all about frying meat that isn’t chicken as if it were chicken.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So you could teach me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Football or chicken-fried meats?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Football. I’m going to Penny’s on Saturday to watch a game with her friends and I don’t want to look like an idiot. I want to blend in.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you want to blend in with Penny’s friends, I’d think looking like an idiot would be the perfect camouflage.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon, please teach me about football. It’ll be fun.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s exactly what my father said. Come to the games, watch the games, week in and week out from the time I was five until I went off to college. Longest seven years of my life.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Please, I’m asking you as a friend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you making this a tier one friendship request?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I really appreciate this.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah. All right, Poindexter, sit down, shut up and listen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s how my father always began our football conversations. And if you’d like, after the game, I’ll take you outside and teach you how to shoot close enough to a racoon that it craps itself.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: When are you going to stop making Cylon toast?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: When I have enough to destroy all the human toast on the battlestar known as Galactica. Is that what you’re wearing to watch football at Penny’s?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s wrong with a football jersey?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nothing. That, however, appears to be a football cocktail dress.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’s the smallest size they had, except the one for dogs. I can’t believe they had one for dogs.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, yes. Canine football fans are a common sight in Texas. Cats, however, refuse to wear sporting apparel. My sister found that out the hard way.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Anyway, wish me luck.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, wait. Am I correct in assuming that your attempt to be accepted by Penny’s peers is based on your desire to ensure your continuing mating privileges with her?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, I wouldn’t put it exactly that way.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How would you put it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, okay, like you said.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Huh. Seems like an awful lot of trouble to go through for intercourse. Don’t you have access to women who will do it for money? By the way, another accepted usage for the term ho.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good-Bye, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hold on I believe that social convention dictate you not arrive empty-Handed. Would you like to bring some Cylon toast?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, no, I’m trying to fit in, not get laughed at.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What’s funny about Cylon toast?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s open.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, pal.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What do you want?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I brought you a little gift. New kite.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: The kite you made me lose was an authentic Patang, an Indian fighting kite that my brother sent to me from New Delhi. It took me a day to put together and two days to paint. This is Hello Kitty.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, but it comes with a little coin purse. Does a Patang?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Wow, you just don’t get it, do you? Buying me something pretty isn’t going to make our problem just go away.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, I admit I haven’t always been the best friend I could be.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You’ve been a sucky friend, a sucky, sucky friend.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Stipulated.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: And you do it all the time. Last week in the mall at Radio Shack, we were looking for a phone with giant numbers for your mother, and I suddenly realize you’re not even there.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I know, I know.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: And where were you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Getting shot down by the girl at Hot Dog on a Stick. But in my defence, she was gorgeous, and working that squeezer to make the lemonade, going up and down and up and down. It was like a free pole dance right in the middle of the food court.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You’re impossible.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, at least I can talk to women without being drunk.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Excuse me, I have selective mutism, a recognized medical disorder. You’re just a douche.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No. You know what? Maybe that’s what this whole thing’s about. You’re not mad at me, you’re mad at yourself.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, I’m mad at you. I hate myself, but I’m mad at you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine. You’re mad at me. I get it. Now, how about we go spend the day together? Just the two of us. We’ll go anywhere you want.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on. Let me take you someplace nice.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I… I do enjoy the La Brea Tar Pits.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really, now? With the traffic and the parking, it’s… okay, fine. The Tar Pits. Let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, why can’t I stay mad at you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Go! Go! Go! Go-Go-Go-Go! Yes! Are you people watching this? Is this amazing or what?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sweetie, that’s a highlight from the ’98 championship game.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Did not know that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How much beer have you had?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: None, why?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh. I was just kind of hoping you were drunk. Now we’re back live.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, yeah. I can see the difference.

utterance.speaker: Guy in baseball hat
utterance.content: Oh, where’s the flag, that’s intentional grounding.

utterance.speaker: Second guy
utterance.content: Totally.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That completely was a forward pass, which they threw intentionally incomplete to avoid loss of yardage or to conserve time. I can’t believe they’re not being penalized with the loss of a down and by having to move the line of scrimmage back to the spot of the foul.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Here, have some pizza, sweetie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny, you know I’m lactose intolerant.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know. I just need you stop talking.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny. Penny. Penny.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, come in.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. I’d like to make a sandwich, but I’m out of bread.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: There’s some in the fridge.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You shouldn’t keep your bread in the refrigerator. Staleness is caused by crystallization of the starch molecules, which occurs faster at cool temperatures.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: On Earth, we say thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So Leonard, how goes the mimesis?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mimesis?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know. Mimesis. An action in which the mimic takes on the properties of a specific object or organism. Mimesis.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What the hell are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m attempting to communicate with you without my meaning becoming apparent to those around you. Let me try again. Have the indigenous fauna accepted you as one of their own? Nudge, nudge, wink, wink.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, I guess so.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good. Oh, FYI. After I eat my sandwich, I’m taking Koothrappali’s Patang kite out for a test run. Would you like to get your delta-wing raptor and join me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t want to fly kites, Sheldon. We’re watching football here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can see that. I was providing you with an alternative. A courtesy I was never offered in similar circumstances.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, look at that. The Oklahoma coach has thrown down a red flag indicating he’s challenging the ruling on the field. I hope he’s right, ’cause if he’s not, it’ll cost him one of his three time-Outs.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, Leonard, honey, I wouldn’t mind if you wanted to go fly kites with Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I’ll watch the end of the game. Besides, there’s only three minutes left.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Until half time.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This is just half? We’ve been here for hours.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And you’re gonna be here for a couple more.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, you’re kidding me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nice meeting all of you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, yeah, anyway, that’s my boyfriend. He is really smart.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I really like my saber-toothed cat. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: My pleasure. Maybe after lunch, we can go to Marie Callender’s and have some pie.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’d like that. This is turning out to be a perfect Saturday.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Good. I’m glad. Oh, man. Did you see the way she smiled at me?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fine. Go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No. This is our day.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: If you want to chase after her, chase after her.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ah, who am I kidding? I wouldn’t have a shot with a girl like that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t put yourself down. You’re a very attractive man.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You think so?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah. Absolutely. It wouldn’t kill you to take a Pilates class with me now and then, but you have a certain wiry appeal.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, well, it doesn’t matter ‘cause she wasn’t really smiling at me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Actually, in this case, I think she was.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What a douche.
